snippet.textDisplay:
This was our last video for the year 12019 of the Human Era. And what a year it was. So much stuff happened everywhere. To so many different people.
Calendars and holidays are just imaginary but they help us to cut our lives into pieces that our brains can handle.
We are leaving 12019 behind with a weird mixture of disillusion and hope. The world is screwed up. But we can fix it. In a few days this year will be over. And we all get to try again.
Thank you for watching our videos and for sticking around for so many years. See you all in 12020.
snippet.textOriginal:
This was our last video for the year 12019 of the Human Era. And what a year it was. So much stuff happened everywhere. To so many different people.
Calendars and holidays are just imaginary but they help us to cut our lives into pieces that our brains can handle.
We are leaving 12019 behind with a weird mixture of disillusion and hope. The world is screwed up. But we can fix it. In a few days this year will be over. And we all get to try again.
Thank you for watching our videos and for sticking around for so many years. See you all in 12020.

snippet.textDisplay: I’m no physicist, but aside from having a device powerful enough to transport the sun, it seems the Sun would be hard to just push due to it’s weight on the fabric of space and time. Is the sun not in essence anchored by it’s gravity?
snippet.textOriginal: I’m no physicist, but aside from having a device powerful enough to transport the sun, it seems the Sun would be hard to just push due to it’s weight on the fabric of space and time. Is the sun not in essence anchored by it’s gravity?

snippet.textDisplay:
Imagine humanity in the future...
The Milky Way is almost fully colonised, almost all the solar systems have a permanent presence of humans in them, but our curiosity is endless, our pursuit of knowledge and adventure are irresistible and our greed for more resources, more than a single galaxy worth of resources are unquenchable. On that era, humans dedicated a whole solar system for extragalactic travel, the spaceship: An entire solar system, consisting of a couple of planets for metals, a couple for gases, a couple for plantation, a couple for water and a couple for major habitation. This solar-system-spaceship consisting of a range of planets for a self-sustaining supply and billions of explorers will venture outside of the Milky Way, waging through the dark expanse of space, relying on the very star propelling the system forward, to a whole new galaxy.
snippet.textOriginal:
*Imagine humanity in the future...*
The Milky Way is almost fully colonised, almost all the solar systems have a permanent presence of humans in them, but our curiosity is endless, our pursuit of knowledge and adventure are irresistible and our greed for more resources, more than a single galaxy worth of resources are unquenchable. On that era, humans dedicated a whole solar system for extragalactic travel, the spaceship: An entire solar system, consisting of a couple of planets for metals, a couple for gases, a couple for plantation, a couple for water and a couple for major habitation. This solar-system-spaceship consisting of a range of planets for a self-sustaining supply and billions of explorers will venture outside of the Milky Way, waging through the dark expanse of space, relying on the very star propelling the system forward, to a whole new galaxy.

snippet.textDisplay: Yea no, moving the sun will bring everything that orbit the sun with it but it has a price. the orbits will be altered(inertia force is applied to any moving object, no matter the size or the speed, when something is starting moving, the inertia force is kicking in) which mean great disturbance for every object orbiting the sun and if you consider that earth is really fragile, this would probably mean a lot of not great things for us. Inertia and gravity fields are used speed up probes going away in the rest of the solar system, it's something well known

snippet.textDisplay: After 6 Years 113 videos have been made on this channel, It's been so cool to watch your style of animation improve after every video. From the first video on your channel to the last video of 12019.  I can see how each video improves in terms of it's quality, for example how more vibrant colours are used in recent videos and how the frame rate is much smoother. Considering how long each video takes to make, a lot of time and effort has clearly been put into this channel. I've started animating as a hobby so watching your videos and observing your style has helped a lot with that and given me something to do over the holidays. If Kurzgesagt is seeing this comment then I'd just like to thank you for creating such high quality content which I get to learn from and occasionally binge if I have nothing else to do.
snippet.textOriginal: After 6 Years 113 videos have been made on this channel, It's been so cool to watch your style of animation improve after every video. From the first video on your channel to the last video of 12019.  I can see how each video improves in terms of it's quality, for example how more vibrant colours are used in recent videos and how the frame rate is much smoother. Considering how long each video takes to make, a lot of time and effort has clearly been put into this channel. I've started animating as a hobby so watching your videos and observing your style has helped a lot with that and given me something to do over the holidays. If Kurzgesagt is seeing this comment then I'd just like to thank you for creating such high quality content which I get to learn from and occasionally binge if I have nothing else to do.

snippet.textDisplay:
You have to move the planets separately. They don't automatically move with it. They stay in the same orbit until they run into something. Or they are far enough to fly out of orbit.
Conservation of angular momentum.
Still if you could move stars, you could put 3 MV red stars together and make a yellow GV .
snippet.textOriginal:
You have to move the planets separately.  They don't automatically move with it. They stay in the same orbit until they run into something.  Or they are far enough to fly out of orbit.
Conservation of angular momentum.  
Still if you could move stars, you could put 3 MV red stars together and make a yellow GV .

snippet.textDisplay:
Not that we are leaving anytime soon, but I am curious..
The reason rockets and Astronauts (with flash light) work is because the fuel (or photons) is being emitted from the same body that is moving.
With Shikadov Thruster, the Sun has already emitted the photons while the Thruster is the one Photons are striking. Wouldn't just the Thruster move in this case (since it is not actually pushing/pulling the sun in any manner)?
snippet.textOriginal:
Not that we are leaving anytime soon, but I am curious..
The reason rockets and Astronauts (with flash light) work is because the fuel (or photons) is being emitted from the same body that is moving.
With Shikadov Thruster, the Sun has already emitted the photons while the Thruster is the one Photons are striking. Wouldn't just the Thruster move in this case (since it is not actually pushing/pulling the sun in any manner)?

snippet.textDisplay:
How to colonize the entire galaxy:
1. Set up tethers around the earth.
2. Construct the first moon bases on the Moon.
3. Use the Helium on the Moon to make fusion reactors on earth and on the moon
4. Construct a ring of solar panels around earth to collect energy.
5. Set up bases on Mars and mercury.
6. Use the moons of Mars to make very big tethers.
7. Mine for water on Ceres to support the Mars bases.
8. Gather uranium form the asteroid belt to power nuclear fission back on earth.
9. Use the iron on Mars to make lots of space ships.
10. Set up orbiting platforms around Jupiter to dock space ships
11. Gather more Helium in Jupiter's atmosphere to power more nuclear fusion
12. Collect resources from the rings of Saturn to terraform Venus.
13. Use rail guns on Mercury to shoot mirrors around the sun.
14. Construct the DYSON SPHERE!!! (swarm)
15. Construct a stellar engine.
16. Arrive at Proxima Centauri and colonize Proxima Centauri b
17. Construct engines around Proxima Centauri, Alpha Centauri A, and Alpha Centauri B.
18. Build a very big Dyson sphere (swarm) around Sirius A.
19. Mine the white dwarf Sirius B for ultra strong carbon material.
20. Move Sirius A and B along with us as well.
21. Send fleets of ultra fast antimatter space ships to V616 Monocerotis.
22. Construct a black hole power plant around V616 Monocerotis.
23. Use the black hole as a slingshot to send space ships to Crab Pulsar.
24. Start colonies around the pulsar when the solar system arrives.
25. Construct a dyson sphere (swarm) around the pulsar.
26. Bring along V616 Monocerotis and the pulsar.
27. Build a quantum computer on Pluto.
28. Calculate the path to the center of the milky way.
29. Start to bring along nearby stars.


TWO MILLION YEARS LATER...


30. Build a power plant around Sagittarius A
31. Park all our the stars we brought with us 1000 light years away from Sag A
32. Thats it...


YAY, YOU MADE IT!
snippet.textOriginal:
How to colonize the entire galaxy:
1. Set up tethers around the earth.
2. Construct the first moon bases on the Moon.
3. Use the Helium on the Moon to make fusion reactors on earth and on the moon
4. Construct a ring of solar panels around earth to collect energy.
5. Set up bases on Mars and mercury.
6. Use the moons of Mars to make very big tethers.
7. Mine for water on Ceres to support the Mars bases.
8. Gather uranium form the asteroid belt to power nuclear fission back on earth.
9. Use the iron on Mars to make lots of space ships.
10. Set up orbiting platforms around Jupiter to dock space ships
11. Gather more Helium in Jupiter's atmosphere to power more nuclear fusion
12. Collect resources from the rings of Saturn to terraform Venus.
13. Use rail guns on Mercury to shoot mirrors around the sun.
14. Construct the DYSON SPHERE!!! (swarm)
15. Construct a stellar engine.
16. Arrive at Proxima Centauri and colonize Proxima Centauri b
17. Construct engines around Proxima Centauri, Alpha Centauri A, and Alpha Centauri B.
18. Build a very big Dyson sphere (swarm) around Sirius A.
19. Mine the white dwarf Sirius B for ultra strong carbon material.
20. Move Sirius A and B along with us as well.
21. Send fleets of ultra fast antimatter space ships to V616 Monocerotis.
22. Construct a black hole power plant around V616 Monocerotis.
23. Use the black hole as a slingshot to send space ships to Crab Pulsar.
24. Start colonies around the pulsar when the solar system arrives.
25. Construct a dyson sphere (swarm) around the pulsar.
26. Bring along V616 Monocerotis and the pulsar.
27. Build a quantum computer on Pluto.
28. Calculate the path to the center of the milky way.

31. Park all our the stars we brought with us 1000 light years away from Sag A

snippet.textDisplay:
Questiom: You say that if we move our Sum, the rest of our neighboring planets would follow.

Is that necessarily true?
Because wouldn't that movement throw off the rotation of each of the planets, making them either escape our Solar System, or swirl back in MUCH closer to our sun?
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: One day, one day. There really are no limits but our curiousity, then dreams and also imagination. We then have the means and ability to apply these dreams into something that actually works in the real world. We are incredible. History has shown nothing but this. If only we could start being actually nice to each other, in my opinion the real progress will then begin.

snippet.textDisplay: Isn't the whole idea of this redundant; our solar system will make one whole revolution around the milky way in 250million years, as stated in the proposed idea. Yet isn't everything else around the galactic edge revolving around the galactic center just the same as we are!? The idea seems sound if not pointless and needless to say thinking on a small scale. If our society ever gets its head out of its collective fear end stops waging political, social and economic wars on its self and by some miracle dosen't destroy its self before we can reach a Tier 3 Civilization that has the means to build anything remotely close to this then why would we stay in the milky way? I mean think about it,  you have the technology, means and knowledge to propel your entire solar system you could still make turns using this method of travel though do to the angles would be a very slow million year turn. You could take this solar system and take it rogue. Using it to take our Civilization and all of the resources of the planets, asteroid belt perhaps even the Ort Cloud with.
snippet.textOriginal: Isn't the whole idea of this redundant; our solar system will make one whole revolution around the milky way in 250million years, as stated in the proposed idea. Yet isn't everything else around the galactic edge revolving around the galactic center just the same as we are!? The idea seems sound if not pointless and needless to say thinking on a small scale. If our society ever gets its head out of its collective fear end stops waging political, social and economic wars on its self and by some miracle dosen't destroy its self before we can reach a Tier 3 Civilization that has the means to build anything remotely close to this then why would we stay in the milky way? I mean think about it,  you have the technology, means and knowledge to propel your entire solar system you could still make turns using this method of travel though do to the angles would be a very slow million year turn. You could take this solar system and take it rogue. Using it to take our Civilization and all of the resources of the planets, asteroid belt perhaps even the Ort Cloud with.

snippet.textDisplay:
I hate science like this. If you're moving an entire solar system to avoid annihilation, you probably have the technology to just go to a new planet. For that matter, I'm pretty certain you would have the technology to stop whatever might be threatening you.


The reason a Dyson Sphere is impossible is because it would take more resources to build it than what you could logically gather into one place. You can't mine ore from the Earth to build a sphere larger than the sun. Or from other planets for that matter. That's not even taking into account how big the sphere would have to be so it doesn't just melt like an ice cream on pavement.



It's why I HATE the Starkiller Base in 'The Force Awakens'. The machines used to build a weapon into the side of a planet could in fact have been used as weapons themselves. They obviously have world destructing capabilities, just need to add some lasers. Not to mention the resources they needed to bring in to build the weapon itself (aside from the resources of the planet itself).
snippet.textOriginal:
I hate science like this.  If you're moving an entire solar system to avoid annihilation, you probably have the technology to just go to a new planet.  For that matter, I'm pretty certain you would have the technology to stop whatever might be threatening you.


The reason a Dyson Sphere is impossible is because it would take more resources to build it than what you could logically gather into one place.  You can't mine ore from the Earth to build a sphere larger than the sun.  Or from other planets for that matter.  That's not even taking into account how big the sphere would have to be so it doesn't just melt like an ice cream on pavement.



It's why I HATE the Starkiller Base in 'The Force Awakens'.  The machines used to build a weapon into the side of a planet could in fact have been used as weapons themselves.  They obviously have world destructing capabilities, just need to add some lasers.  Not to mention the resources they needed to bring in to build the weapon itself (aside from the resources of the planet itself).
